RDU.value: A security that represents ownership in a corporation. Holders of common stock exercise control by electing a board of directors and can have voting rights. Common stockholders are on the bottom of the priority ladder for payment rank
A class of ownership in a corporation that has a higher claim on the assets and earnings than common stock. Income is distributed through scheduled payments to the holders
Parent Asset Type of all types of funds - mutual funds, pension funds, hedge funds etc

A negotiable financial instrument issued by a bank to represent a foreign company's publicly traded securities. Number of different types of depositary receipts including ADR, GDR, BDR, CRD, EDR, IDR etc.  are supported. Shares of the underlying security are held on deposit and under certain circumstances may be swapped for the receipt.

An investment company that offers a fixed, unmanaged portfolio, generally of stocks and bonds, as redeemable "units" to investors for a specific period of time. It is designed to provide capital appreciation and/or dividend income. Its securities will not be sold or new ones bought except in certain limited situations (bankruptcy, merger, etc.).

The fund that actively manages a portfolio of investments that uses advanced investment strategies such as leveraged, long, short and derivative positions in both domestic and international markets with the goal of generating high returns with optimum risk. Hedge funds are included under this category.

A mutual fund is an investment vehicle made up of a pool of moneys collected from many investors for the purpose of investing in securities such as stocks, bonds, money market instruments and other assets. Mutual funds are operated by professional money managers, who allocate the fund's investments and attempt to produce capital gains and/or income for the fund's investors. A mutual fund's portfolio is structured and maintained to match the investment objectives stated in its prospectus. Investors in a mutual fund must pay management fees and other expenses.
Includes open and closed end funds, tradable on an exchange or not. Excludes ETFs.

An ETF is a security that tracks an index or a commodity or a basket of assets like an index fund, and trades like a stock on an exchange. It is a type of fund that owns the underlying assets (shares of stock, bonds, oil futures, gold bars, foreign currency, etc.). Shareholders do not directly own or have any direct claim to the underlying investments in the fund although they are entitled to a proportion of the profits, such as earned interest or dividends paid, and they may get a residual value in case the fund is liquidated. ETFs experience price changes throughout the day as they are bought and sold, and typically have higher daily liquidity and lower fees than mutual funds.

A REIT, or real estate investment trust, is a company that owns and in most cases operates income-producing real estate such as apartments, office buildings, warehouses, shopping centers, regional malls, or hotels. A small percentage of REITs (mortgage REITs) lend money to owners of real estate and therefore do not have direct ownership of the asset. They can be publicly traded, public yet non listed, or private. REITs offer investors access to commercial property returns without the barriers to entry associated with  traditional property ownership (mainly large price tags and illiquidity). In this way, REITs allow investors to own a “piece” of a mall or apartment building by simply owning shares of a REIT stock.
For RDU purposes, shares of a REIT will be included in asset type REIT, even though they may be common shares (in those cases of publicly traded REITs).

A fund established by an employer or an intermediary to facilitate and organize the investment of employees' retirement funds contributed by the employer and employees. Pension funds are commonly run by some sort of financial intermediary for the company and its employees, although some larger corporations operate their pension funds in-house. This category will include both open and closed ended funds

A Royalty trust is a type of corporate structure whereby a cash flow stream from a designated set of assets (typically oil and gas reserves) is paid to shareholders in the form of cash dividends (on either a monthly, or a quarterly basis). A trust’s profit is not taxed at the corporate level provided that a certain percentage (e.g., 90%) of profit is distributed to shareholders as dividends. The dividends are then taxed as personal income. Unlike MLPs, U.S. trusts are not actively managed entities. Thus, they do not make acquisitions or increase their asset base. In addition, U.S. royalty trusts typically have no debt, which also reflects the royalty nature of their business. The U.S. royalty trusts’ cash flow is paid to investors as it is generated only until the underlying asset is depleted. As a result, dividends from trusts fluctuate with cash flow and should eventually dissipate.
Parent Asset Type of all equity related products. Equity refers to shares of ownership in publicly held companies
All other equity instruments not listed above

All other funds that cannot be accomodated in the above fund types but the type is known, then it is classified under 'Other Fund'. Unknown/Unclassifiable funds are classified under the parent asset type 'Fund'

MLPs are publicly traded limited liability companies or partnerships that are traded in an exchange or OTC. They combine the tax advantages of a partnership (profits and income are taxed only when income is distributed to participants, the partnership as a whole does not pay income tax, so double taxation is avoided) and the liquidity of publicly traded companies. At least 90% of the gross income the MLP earns each year must be considered eligible income for the company to qualify as an MLP. Eligible income are mostly interest, dividends, rents and profits/gains from the sale of assets and property. Losses are not included in these calculations. Income is added on a yearly basis and tested for the 90% eligibility criterion. If the test is not passed, the company loses the MLP status permanently (there are certain cases in which this loss of status may be reversible though). MLPs are actively managed entities that can make acquisitions and investments to increase their asset base and sustain (and grow) cash flow. Over the long term, traditional MLP distributions are managed to be steady and sustainable (and often growing).
Securities created by pooling loans, other securities and/or parts of securities

Pass-through securities are instruments that pool loans together. The cash flows are distributed to the holders of the securities, and go directly from the borrowers' payments to the investors. Therefore, investors are subject and exposed to credit, prepayment, and extension risks. NOTE: The latter two are the risks associated to the time left to maturity or full payoff of the securities being altered by market forces. When a security pays off earlier than planned, the investor will not get the totality of interest payments she was expecting initially (as the loan borrower pays off her mortgage sooner than expected, possibly from refinancing the loan in a lower interest rate environment). Conversely, when a security "lasts" longer than expected, it takes a longer time for the investor to recover her investment. This is the case for example when  payments in the mortgage pool are delayed owing to delinquencies, the life of the pass-through security being extended.

ABS are Instruments that are backed by any asset with a revenue stream such as mortgage loans, credit card receivables, car-loan payments, leasing payments, project finance loans, aircraft receivables, student loans, home equity loan cash flows ... ABS can be viewed as the first layer of securitization. A pool of loans is bundled together, and bonds are issued on the back of that pool ("securitization"). The cash flows from the underlying loans are distributed to the pass-through securities that constitute the ABS. These securities are divided into classes or tranches, which have access to the pool's cash flow on either a pro rata or sequential basis. These classes or "tranches", could all have different average lives, coupons, and risk profiles to attract new and different investors. The more "senior" tranches are higher on the hierarchy of payments. The less senior tranches (the "mezzanine" and "equity" tranches) are last in the hierarchy and will pay off at a later time.

A debt security issued by a subnational entity: state, municipality or county to finance its capital expenditures. Some municipal bonds are issued to raise funds for companies operating in the locality of the issuing authority.

A savings certificate entitling the bearer to receive interest. A CD bears a maturity date, a specified fixed interest rate and can be issued in any denomination. CDs are generally issued by commercial banks. CDs are also covered by FDIC insurance in the US.
An instrument offered by an investment company or brokerage firm designed to offer a competitive yield to an investor with the added safety of their principal.

Bonds issued by a national government in a foreign or local currency, in order to finance the issuing country's growth. Bills, Notes and Bonds are all included in this asset class. Includes also GSE (Government sponsored entities).

Parent asset type of all instruments that pay a rate of interest and return investor's principal at maturity. Fixed income is a type of investment in which real return rates or periodic income is received at regular intervals and at reasonably predictable levels.

An instrument with financing obligation issued by a bank or similar financial institution to a company or individual that holds legal claim to the borrower's assets above all other debt obligations. The loan is considered senior to all other claims against the borrower, which means that in the event of a bankruptcy the senior bank loan is the first to be repaid, before all other interested parties receive repayment.
A note (maturities between 1 and 10 years) that is linked to the performance of a reference instrument such as equity, currency, Index etc.

CMO's are products made of a pool of pass-through securities, and not a pool of actual loans or mortgages; thus, CMO's can be viewed as the second layer of the securitization. Tranches of mortgage backed securities are bundled  to create a CMO. They are distributed within the CMO according to credit risk in different tranches or classes. The basic structure of a CMO pays sequentially through its tranches. All tranches receive interest payments, but it is the most senior tranche that gets principal payments until that tranche is fully paid, and retired. Then all principal payments go to the second tranche until it is paid off, and so on. This allows the issuer to distribute prepayment/extension risk along the different classes, and contributes to a higher predictability for the more senior tranches.

All unsecured, short-term debt instruments issued by a corporation, typically for the financing of accounts receivable, inventories and meeting short-term liabilities. Maturities on commercial paper rarely range any longer than 270 days.
A synthetic bond is a mixture of investments designed to mimic the cash flow and risk profile of a bond, usually through the use of options, credit default swaps and other instruments.

A dividend is a distribution of a portion of a company's earnings, decided by the board of directors, paid to a class of its shareholders. Dividends can be issued as cash payments, as shares of stock, or other property.
Synthetic dividends: A type of incoming cash flow that an investor creates with certain financial securities to produce a dividend-like payment stream that resembles the periodic cash receipts from a dividend-paying stock.

A short-term debt instrument issued by a firm that is guaranteed by a commercial bank. Banker's acceptances are issued by firms as part of a commercial transaction. These instruments are similar to T-Bills and are frequently used in money market funds.

A negotiable promissory note issued by a bank and payable to the bearer on demand. The amount payable is stated on the face of the note. Banknotes are considered legal tender, and, along with coins, make up the bearer forms of all modern money.

Bearer Deposit Notes are used by clients who prefer to invest in short-term, marketable, bank-issued instruments. They are sold in bearer form at a discount to their face value. As a negotiable instrument, they can be sold back to bank (or on the secondary market) at prevailing market rates at any time prior to maturity.
All other fixed income that cannot be classified into the above categories.

A negotiable financial instrument issued by a bank to represent a foreign company's debt securities. Number of different types of depositary receipts including ADR, GDR, BDR, CDR, EDR, IDR etc.  are supported. Bonds of the underlying security are held on deposit and under certain circumstances may be swapped for the receipt.
Base metals such as Iron, copper, aluminium etc
Precious metals including Gold, Silver etc

Parent asset type of all physical commodities including metals, grains etc. Includes Good Delivery Vault Receipts (GDVRs), for example precious metals receipts.
Under this parent asset type, commodity price fixings or assesments carried out by an exchange or price assesment agencies are included (e.g. For Freight, only this type is used)
In other cases, actual commodities for physical delivery are included instead or in addition the commodity price fixings or assesments (e.g. Agricultural Commodities, Oil, Emission Certificates, etc)
All grades and varieties of oil including Brent crude, Bonny light etc
All kinds of oil seeds including Soya
Consumable electricity delivered on the grid
Other structured products not mentioned above

A single residential or commercial mortgage that a lender has issued to a borrower and that has not been securitized. Whole loan lenders commonly sell their whole loans in the secondary mortgage market to buyers such as Fannie Mae.
Commodities products that are based on relationship between two different energy commodities
Compressed Natural Gas, Liquid Petroleum Gas etc

A debt security issued by a corporation and sold to investors. The backing for the bond is usually the payment ability of the company, which is typically money to be earned from future operations. In some cases, the company's physical assets may be used as collateral for bonds. Supranational issues will be included in the corporate bond category.
Agricultural products that do not fall under grains, oilseeds or timber. These include coffee, cocoa, sugar, etc.
Freight rates for dry bulk carriers. These include the transportation of traded dry bulk freight such as coal, iron ore and grains.
Commodities products that are based on relationship between two different commodity asset types
Commodities products that are used for feed for humans or animals not included in Softs, Grains, Seafood or Livestock.
Agricultural products that do not fall under grains, oilseeds, timber, foodstuffs or softs
Commodities products that are harvested from the ocean or fresh water for consumption
Plastics are organic compounds, fully or partially synthetic, that are malleable and can become solid.
Energy products not included in Coal, gas, oil or electricity
Renewable energy is energy that is generated from natural processes that are continuously replenished. This includes sunlight, geothermal heat, wind, tides, water, and various forms of biomass.

Parent assset type of all instruments that gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an asset at a set price on or before a given date. In case of option on futures, they are classified based on the asset type of the ultimate underlying
Freight rates for tankers and containerships.  These include the transportation of traded liquid freight such as crude oil, refined products, natural gas liquids as well as liquid natural gas.

Options on underlying single stock equities, funds, depositary receipts and other forms of Equity. These options due to corporate action may also have other asset types e.g. reorganization warrants, cash, bonds, etc. This asset type excludes Options on ETFs.
Options on equity Indices such as FTSE 100 and S&P 500
Option to buy or sell a bond at a certain price on or before the option expiry date. These instruments are typically traded OTC.
Options on Indices that track a basket of commodities to measure their performance. Ex : Reuters/Jefferies CRB Index,  Dow Jones Commodity Index
Options on Commodities such as oil, dairy products, energy, weather,etc

Options of which the underlying is the price of a currency (an exchange rate) or the price of a currency future contract (in the case of an OOF). This price will be expressed as an exchange rate. NOTE: This asset type classification will also apply to Currency Index Options and to Options on Currency Index Futures.

Option on dividend Indices such as  S&P 500 Annual Dividend Index (DIVD) and the S&P 500 Dividend Index (DVS). Dividend Index options contracts provide direct exposure to the dividend risk of the index.This classification includes both single stock dividend option and index dividend option
Option on underlying Exchange Traded Funds such as iShares MSCI emerging markets Asia Index ETF, or ETNs (exchange traded notes).

An Interest rate option is a specific financial derivative contract/instrument whose value is based on interest rates. Its value is tied to an underlying interest rate, such as the yield on 10 year treasury bonds. Will include interest rate index and other possible money market interest underlying instruments, but it will exclude swaptions <which the ultimate underlying is a IRS swap, which is an interest rate derivative>

The option to enter into an interest rate swap. In exchange for an option premium, the buyer gains the right but not the obligation to enter into a specified swap agreement with the issuer on a specified future date.
Options used to hedge credit exposure
Parent assset type of all contracts for assets (especially commodities or shares) bought at agreed prices but delivered and paid for later.
All other options which don’t fall into one of the above categories is classified as 'Other Options'
A future that has an equity index as its underlying.
An agreement to buy or sell a set amount of a commodity at a predetermined price and date. The underlying commodities include oil, dairy products, weather, energy, metals, etc

Futures on underlying single stock equities, funds, depositary receipts and other forms of Equity. These futures due to corporate action may also have other asset types e.g. reorganization warrants, cash, bonds, etc. This asset type excludes Futures on ETFs.
Futures on ETFs (exchange traded funds), or ETNs (exchange traded notes).
Futures that specify the price of a currency at a future date. This price will be expressed as an exchange rate. NOTE: This asset type classification will also apply to Currency Index futures.

An interest rate future is a financial derivative (a futures contract) with an interest rate NOT associated to an issued security (i.e. not associated to the yield of a bond, or its coupon) as the underlying asset. The most usual form of interest rate futures is that referenced to interbank rates, repo rates or central bank rates. NOTE: Many exchanges and conventions classify futures that have a bond or basket of bonds, and those who have an interest rate, as underliers , under the "Interest rate futures" category. Please note that this is NOT the case for RDU.
Futures on single stock dividend or dividend Index.

Contracts that allow people to buy or sell a specific type of asset at a specific time at a given price. Futures contracts are exchange-traded and, therefore, are standardized contracts. Forward contracts, on the other hand, are private agreements between two parties (Over the counter)  and are not as rigid in their stated terms and conditions. FX forwards are included in this category,

A bond future is a contractual obligation for the contract holder to purchase or sell a bond on a specified date at a predetermined price. The underlying can be an specific bond, a basket of bonds (deliverable basket, of which the seller of the futures contract can deliver any), a rolling reference (E.g. generic denomination of "5 yr benchmark german government bond", which refers to a different bond, normally, replaceable every 3-6 months) or a notional bond. When the underlying is a notional bond, at the delivery date, the seller of the future has the option to deliver any of the deliverable bonds from a basket of eligible bonds selected by the exchange. Normally, the CTD (cheapest to deliver) is chosen by the seller as it is the economically the most beneficial for him. NOTE: This asset type will include both cash and physically settled derivatives, regardless of settlement calculation method, i.e. regardless of what the reference for calculations is (a converted cash price for a notional bond, the actual future's price, or the actual cash price of the deliverable bond, in those cases in which only ONE bond is deliverable). This asset type will also include futures on Treasury bills, notes or bonds (from 3 months maturity and longer), regardless of the coupon type (fixed, floater , zero, issued at discount, etc) of the underlying instrument (bill, note or bond) or the maturity of the underlying.
All other futures that are not included in one of the above are classified in this category
Futures contracts overlying an interest rate swap or interest rate swap index.
Asset type that encapsulates cash, cross rates and spot rates with USD for most foreign exchange transactions
Futures that help manage the exposure to credit risk. Futures on Credit default Swaps are included under this category.
Currency rates based on USD rates traded and settled in cash
Currency rates traded and settled in cashat current market prices, as opposed to forward prices
Indices on Currency - Currency Indices may be used as a tool to help investors manage foreign currency exposure in their international portfolio. For example, MSCI EAFE Currency [USD] Index
A basket refers to a group of assets to be used as underlying of a derivative, or a floater or linked note. They can include different asset types, e.g. an equity, a bond, a warrant, etc.

These are Indices that are constructed to track the expectation of implied market volatility. Examples include, VIX tracks the S&P 500, the VXN tracks the Nasdaq 100 and the VXD tracks the Dow Jones Industrial Average.
Indices on equities; ex - S&P 500, Nikkei 225, DJIA etc
Includes all kinds of Interbank rates such as LIBOR, EURIBOR etc
Indices that track credit derivative market particularly Credit Default Swaps

An index that tracks a basket of commodities to measure their performance. Derivatives of these Indices are often traded on exchanges, allowing investors to gain easier access to commodities without having to enter the futures market. Ex: Reuters/Jefferies CRB Index. Note: Not to be regarded as a Commodity Index is a final settlement price of 1 commodity calculated as an average of multiple prices.

Indices on Fixed Income securities; This Index can be categorized based on its broad characteristics, such as whether they are composed of government bonds, municipal bonds, corporate bonds, high-yield bonds, mortgage-backed securities, syndicated or leveraged loans, etc. They can also be classified based on their credit rating or maturity. 
In example of fixed income index is  FTSE Sterling Corporate Bond Index

An index that measures the performance of stocks of companies which usually pay higher than average dividends. These stocks are required to have a consistent ranking and history of dividend payouts over a specific period of time to be included in the index.

A measure of the prices at which houses are bought and sold. Housing indexes may encompass different areas such as city, metropolitan area, region, or country, or different market segments, like new houses only, or resales. In some cases they cover segments attending to build quality or location. Housing indexes are indicators of house price inflation, which may or may not be included in the official CPI calculations.

Economic data, of macroeconomic scale, that is used by investors to interpret current or future investment possibilities and judge the overall health of an economy. Includes --  Consumer Price Index (CPI), Retail Price Index (RPI), Producer Price Index (PPI)
- Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth rate 
- Unemployment figures
It also includes market indicators such as volume of shares traded, volatility etc

All other Indices that are not included in the above list of Indices. Some specific index types will be included in this definition in order to facilitate asset type allocation to the analyst.
- Real Estate Indices - Not to be mistaken with Asset Type "Housing Index". Real Estate Indices are real estate metrics related indices which do not belong to separate Asset type "Housing Index" (please refer to "Housing Index" definition), i.e. Property Investmet return Index, Commercial Real Estate Prices Index , etc.
Include macro market level statistics such as Volume of Shares traded, Volatility
Includes Non-Financial economic indicators such as CPI, PPI, RPI, GDP growth rate, unemployment figures etc
An instrument produced by combining several stocks or other investment vehicles together and expressing their total values against a base value from a specific date.
Swaps are derivatives that exchange different cashflows  which are typically bilateral contracts and traded over the counter but can be cleared on an exchange. CFDs are classified as Swaps.

One stream of future interest payments is exchanged for another based on a specified principal amount. Interest rate swaps often exchange a fixed payment for a floating payment that is linked to an interest rate (most often the LIBOR).

Swaps on volatility Indices such as VSTOXX. The VSTOXX® volatility index expresses the fluctuation range expected by the market, that is the implied volatility of the EURO STOXX 50® Index. The VSTOXX® indicates in percentage points which volatility is to be expected for the EURO STOXX 50® Index over the coming 30 days.

The two sets of nominally equal cash flows are exchanged as per the terms of the swap, which may involve an equity-based cash flow (such as from a stock asset) that is traded for a fixed-income cash flow (such as a benchmark rate). Includes Contract for Difference

A swap designed to transfer the credit exposure of fixed income products between parties. A credit default swap is also referred to as a credit derivative contract, where the purchaser of the swap makes payments up until the maturity date of a contract. Payments are made to the seller of the swap. In return, the seller agrees to pay off a third party debt if this party defaults on the loan. A CDS is considered insurance against non-payment.

A derivative that is used by individuals to mitigate the effects of potentially large levels of inflation. In an inflation swap, a counterparty's cash flows are linked to a price index and the other counterparty is linked to a conventional fixed or floating cash flow.
A swap that involves the exchange of principal and interest in one currency for the same in another currency.
All other Swaps that are not included in the above such as total return swap, Credit default Index swaps options etc

Strategies are the simultaneous, and often mixed, buying or selling of one or more options and futures that differ in one or more of the options' and/or future's variables. This is often done to gain exposure to a specific type of opportunity or risk while eliminating other risks as part of a trading strategy.
Strategies that are built with various futures as underlyings
Strategies that are built with various options as underlyings
Stratagies that have other strategy products as its underlyings
Strategies that are created synthetically by combining various short and long positions
Packages of different financial instruments issued and/or traded as one single unit (also referred to as staple security). They can be separated during their life cycle and be traded individually.
A swap in which exchanged cash flows are dependent on the price of an underlying commodity. A commodity swap is usually used to hedge against the price of a index.
Package of multiple bonds with different characteristics issued and/or traded as one single unit.
Package of multiple shares with different characteristics issued and/or traded as one single unit. Included in this category are both common shares and preferred shares.
Package of a share and a bond issued and/or traded as one single unit. Included in this category are both common shares and preferred shares.
Package of multiple warrants with different characteristics issued and/or traded as one single unit.
Package of a fund unit and other financial intruments issued and/or traded as one single unit.
Package of a share and a warrant issued and/or traded as one single unit. Included in this category are both common shares and preferred shares.
Combination of different financial instruments issued and/or traded as one single unit which does not fall into any of the other categories from above.
Financial instruments providing the holder with the privilege to subscribe to or to receive specific assets on terms specified.
A swap in which exchanged cash flows are dependent on the price of an underlying commodity. A commodity swap is usually used to hedge against the price of a commodity.

Stock warrants are rights to buy or right to sell a stock at a certain price until a predetermined date. Similar to call options and put options, investors can exercise stock warrants at a fixed price.

A security giving stockholders entitlement to purchase new shares issued by the corporation at a predetermined price (normally at a discount to the current market price) in proportion to the number of shares already owned. Rights are issued only for a short period of time, after which they expire. Also includes the subtypes such as allotment rights, subscription rights and purchase rights

Mini-futures combine the structure of open-end certificates with leverage option. Mini-futures have no fixed term. The leverage is therefore available without a term restriction. The price of a mini-future always corresponds to its intrinsic value, i.e. the capital outlay, plus the bid-ask spread. The financing costs associated with building up the leverage effect are offset against the capital outlay on a daily basis, thereby eliminating the need for a premium. Investors have to pay only financing costs they actually utilize. In contrast to options, factors like volatility, have no influence at all on the price of mini-futures.
